QuestionNodes.question: Generalized assumptions regarding appropriate academic conduct in Western educational institutions.
QuestionNodes.correct: Western assumptions often lead to misunderstandings about academic integrity among students from different cultural backgrounds.
QuestionNodes.wrong: Western assumptions often lead to misunderstandings about academic integrity among students from different cultural backgrounds.

QuestionNodes.question: Information that is considered commonly understood in some cultures may be viewed differently across cultures, affecting student perceptions of whether it should be referenced.
QuestionNodes.correct: What is considered common knowledge can vary significantly between cultures, impacting perceptions of academic integrity.
QuestionNodes.wrong: What is considered common knowledge can vary significantly between cultures, impacting perceptions of academic integrity.

QuestionNodes.question: Must be specified and sanctioned in Western institutions; otherwise, it may be viewed as cheating.
QuestionNodes.correct: In Western institutions, unsanctioned collaborative work is often seen as academic misconduct.
QuestionNodes.wrong: In Western institutions, unsanctioned collaborative work is often seen as academic misconduct.

QuestionNodes.question: Cultures where group work is accepted and encouraged, even during exams and assignments.
QuestionNodes.correct: Collectivist cultures often encourage helping fellow students, which can be seen as cheating in Western contexts.
QuestionNodes.wrong: Collectivist cultures often encourage helping fellow students, which can be seen as cheating in Western contexts.

QuestionNodes.question: A university policy based on Western ideals of academic integrity and standards upheld in Canada.
QuestionNodes.correct: UNF follows Western standards of academic integrity, which may differ from those in other cultures.
QuestionNodes.wrong: UNF follows Western standards of academic integrity, which may differ from those in other cultures.
